meta_data.title: Esther Asks for a Purge of All the Politicians Who Are Trying to Kill All the Jews
meta_data.subtitle: ESTHER 9 Thanks to everyone who supports TMBH at  You're the reason we can all do this together!  Opening song, "" from the album, "" by

transcription_data.text: I'm hanging out with my family and they all run in do something the other day. It's a Friday afternoon when this happened, probably about four in the afternoon. My family's all inside. So I got a minute. I stared at my phone like an idiot looking at Twitter, X, whatever, scrolling the for you tab. I don't even know how those things are considered for me. But I started to realize that what I'm seeing happening in real time is a purge, a purge that's happening politically within a business that has been a very prominent, probably the most newsworthy software business here of the last year. And something's going down. Some see in all these tweets from names I vaguely recognize and it's stuff about. I don't know what's going on here. Something happened. They're like, I just lost access to the server. Other people are like, I went out to my car, tried to come back in the keypad isn't working. What's going on? And then other people in real time are like, I just got told four minutes before end of workday that I am no longer needed at this place. And people are apologizing and angry. Whoa. This is like the historic purges that I read about throughout the history of the world where with one fell swoop in one bold moment, one group gets the upper hand and they don't wait for the other team to be able to figure out what's going on. They act with impunity and rapidity and boom. The other side is just gone. Now this is a business purge. So it's a big deal, but I don't think anybody died. I mean, I see that particular tweet, but it changed a lot of people's lives and it represents a massive overhaul in power. But historically when we see this happen, no, people die. Purges are a thing. My friends, very famously, there was a whole culture of purge in the last 100 years, maybe 80 years before the birth of Christ and the late Roman Republic. It turned super purgy and eventually it became a thing where if you've got a legion and you have the upper hand politically, it became normalized to send around the brute squad in the middle of the night and all it wants wipe out a whole bunch of your political enemies. This happened multiple times. And of course it changed the way people existed and interacted with their neighbors because they knew if you'd cast in with the wrong person, you might get purged. Your kids, your wife, your family, your whole household might get purged. It's very dark stuff. I guess you could call this a purge as well, but in the 14th century in France, the Knights Templar, they were a banking order of knights and crusaders and they had money that they could move back and forth with an early checking system between the Holy Land and Western Europe. And they got more rich and more powerful than the king. And so famously on one Friday, the 13th and a bunch of pre-dawn raids, all the Knights Templar get rounded up. It would be like if somebody fight club to all the banks and credit institutions in just one day in our country sent shockwaves through the whole economic and political system of France at that time. Speaking of France, how about the reign of terror during the French Revolution? That got super purgy, right? You remember this stuff from school? Is the 1790s, 1790? I don't actually remember when. Hang on. There's a, I got a robot right here that tells me facts about things. September of 1793 to July of 1794, the normalization of guillotining your political enemies had happened. And then somebody else got the upper hand and in one fell swoop, they started guillotining and purging people. And the whole reign of terror thing, that phase of the French Revolution is very estuary, very hamony, I should say, and that a whole lot of people who built guillotines ended up getting guillotined on their own guillotines. And so purges, they tend to backfire. They can be effective. They're one of the most horrifying categories of human activities to read about in all of human history. And I bet you've been through a purge. I bet you know somebody who's been through a purge. I mean, I know for a fact that some of you who are listening have been through this in a political violence kind of way. But the majority of you, I would guess, have at least seen an institutional clean out like what I was seeing on Twitter the other day. It's gross. It's terrifying. It's disruptive. It's also one of those to the victor go the spoils zero some games kind of thing. You show your hand and try to carry out a purge. You better dang well when all morality of it aside. There's no messing around. Once you cross that Rubicon, you're going scorched earth when defeat every single political enemy and leave none of them to come back and bite you. In fact, that first set of purges that I referenced talking about Rome, Cornelius Sulla was a purger. He was a Roman aristocrat and power broker and he purged a bunch of his enemies, enemies of the old ways of the republic at one point. But there was one kid who he reluctantly decided to leave alive and wow, did he regret it even shortly after leaving that kid out of the purge and that was Julius Caesar. So one of the lessons of history is if you're going to do it, you better win. That's the conundrum. That's the situation that we've been talking about yesterday and today that we're seeing in Esther chapter nine because our beloved main human character of the story, the lovely, noble, beautiful, shrewd, but also formidable. Queen Esther is now in a position where at least for a moment she's got the political up her hand and maybe with modern sensibilities as we're reading through the story, we're kind of reading through that little crease in our fingers and we're hoping that she won't be purgy because it's so terrifying. When somebody goes into purge mode, it's like when my dog was fighting that marmot that one time and I finally cut up with her, I was like, you can't kill marmots. What are you doing? Stop with the marmot killing and the dog looks up at me. And her eyes are totally black. Oh, that's not my dog. What is going on here? I'm just going to back away slowly. Never been like that before. Never been like that since. Once people get into purge mode, it's like you don't even recognize them. We don't want Esther to go there. We want her to be nice. We want her to do some kind of thing where she's merciful to her enemies and then her enemies are like, I guess we all made some mistakes here today. We shouldn't have tried to commit genocide against you and eliminate every single Jew from civilization. But now that you've shown us mercy, we've reconsidered how we feel about Jews and we're not racist anymore. And then everybody is happy and high fives and frees fame and the credit roll is great and everything's fine. But that isn't really usually how these things play out. And so we read through our fingers into Esther chapter nine. And sure enough, it looks like our beloved Esther is going to participate in a purge and it looks like she's going to be the driving force behind this episode of violence flipping from a repulsion of an attempted genocide against the Jews to not just that, but also okay, we held our ground and now we're going to take ground by eliminating every political rival surrounding the throne, surrounding the citadel of Sousa who would imagine ever rising up trying to get the upper hand again and coming back on us. Here's how that reads Esther nine starting in verse 11. Let's go with that. The number of those slain in the citadel of Sousa was reported to the king that same day. The king said to Esther that Jews have killed and destroyed 500 men and 10 sons of Haman and the citadel of Sousa and he kind of muses to himself that side his mind right there. Now we're back to the text. What have they done in the rest of the king's provinces? But rather than taking that off ramp, the king who's abdicated decision making an authority at every turn in this book turns to Esther and he says, now what's your petition? It'll be giving you what's your request. It will also be granted that phrase hasn't worked great for him, but that's still the way he's playing things. And now depending on how you look at it, Esther furrows her brow and musters the courage again to do what needs to be done or again, depending on how you view it, the black goes over her eyes and she says, if it pleases the king, Esther answered, give the Jews and Sousa permission to carry out this day's edict tomorrow also and let Haman's 10 sons be hanged on gallows. That's purge language. I'm not even prepared to say that she's wrong. I understand that's a jarring comment. I don't know what to do with this. It makes my compass spin. I'm very comfortable and I live in a very comfortable environment where I don't have to do purges. And the few times I've been around it politically or organizationally, I'm aghast. You don't sleep. You stew. You pace. You work things over a hundred different ways. It's painful. It's confusing. It's disorienting. It changes the trajectories of people's lives. But those are just organizational purges. Ain't nobody dying here. We're talking about households. I mean, look, they just got done killing 10 sons of Haman. I mean, I assume these are adult sons for the most part, but I'm guessing based on the fact that he has 10 sons. Let me see. That's nine months takes at least a minute or two in between. So that's 90 months add on 10%. And if every last one of them is Irish twins, are you still allowed to say Irish twins? I don't mean any disrespect to the Irish. I think that's just what you call it when you have two kids born in the same year. Call that 120 months at the absolute minimum. But I mean, poor Zaresh and Skaz got to be more than that. What are we talking about a range of 15 years minimum and age difference between these sons? I bet some of them were young. I also bet some of them were more than old enough to be completely complicit and on board with the plan to kill all of the Jews. The point is this is not a singularly horrible thing that only happened once in all of history. This is unfortunately a pretty common thing that happens throughout history as we've discussed. And now the opportunity is at the feet of Esther to try to throttle it back and see if she can count on the goodwill and the milk of human kindness from the people who tried to kill every man, woman and child of her people group. Or if using the political tools that are expected of the day, which is political purging in the capital is the more prudent thing for her to do. We don't see any approval on the page from God. We don't see any disapproval. We see a statement of what happened and what she picked. And the question I guess I want to leave us with is if you can even imagine yourself in a different reality, a different world, a different role, a different political state, a different opportunity to save your people and protect them in the future at the expense. Maybe if something that's going to take a huge chunk out of your own soul and maybe your own reputation, what do you do? What do you do? Not what ought you to say, but sincerely what would be your move? Maybe I'm asking you to think about something that's too dark. Maybe the text is asking us to think about something that's too dark. Maybe the text written in an ancient world context is just simply happy that the people from whose point of view the text is written didn't all get killed. And that's enough. And I'm reading in a moral conflict that certainly would exist for us, but that didn't exist for them. I want to work through this exchange between the king and Esther further and the strategic trudeness or lack thereof of how Esther chooses to play it next time around. Sometimes these conversations are bright and perky and fun. Sometimes they take us to very difficult places. I think this might be mostly the latter. Oh, well, we get what we get. That's why we just go straight through the thing and whatever's next is whatever's next. And with that, ha, we'll just go think about it. All right. I'm Matt. This is a 10 minute Bible Hour podcast. Let's do this again soon.
